item.title: 50% off The Bagelry
item.description:
Scout Notes: There’s no question about what you’ll find inside The San Francisco Bagelry. Not only is their livelihood boldly presented in the business’ name, there’s a bagel hanging on the storefront that could be spotted from the top of Coit Tower, if you were a bird at least. But when you know how to do bagels up right like these guys do, you let the world know. While a lot of “the other guys” are busy steaming their bagels, the crew at The Bagelry is doing everything by hand, the old fashioned way, to produce chewy, New York style bagels. What you’ll find in the display cases here are dense, boiled bagels, not the flimsy bread dough types you’ve probably suffered through before. No bagel is complete without a good schmear of cream cheese, which The Bagelry makes from scratch, as evidenced by the rows of plastic containers topped with little shavings of fresh produce like veggies, chives and strawberries.

On weekdays, bagels come rolling out of the bagel machine in the back until about 9:30 a.m., while weekends require two baking sessions due to demand, and a line that’s consistently out the door. Check out the Really Seedy bagel, topped with sesame and poppy seeds, onion, garlic and a touch of salt. And if you can’t choose between all the scrumptious flavors, don’t worry, you can take these babies home by the dozens, too.

Menu Highlights:
One Dozen Bagels, $10.75
Peanut Butter & Bananas Bagel, $2.50
Lox & Cream Cheese, $6.75
Egg, Sausage, Cheese Breakfast Bagel Sandwich, $5
Egg & Bacon Breakfast Bagel Sandwich, $4
Roast Turkey Bagel Sandwich, $6
Pastrami Bagel Sandwich, $6

Hours:
Monday – Friday, 6:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.
Saturday – Sunday, 7 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.

item.title: What to Do This Weekend, November 18-20
item.description:
We’ve been getting second and third helpings at meals lately in preparation for Thanksgiving. The more we stretch our stomach out now, the more pieces of turkey and pie we can pack in there on the big day. But, in between training for the upcoming holiday, you can bet your britches we’ll be hanging out here:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

THREAD: INDIE DESIGN & FASHION AT THE METREON
Sunday, November 20, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Holiday shopping. Either you can prepare yourself to hear that phrase about a gazmillion times over the next few months, or you can get it over with now and put your earmuffs on the next time the subject comes up. Thread Show is a traveling showcase of top notch indie fashion. Shopping is just the beginning of what’s going down at this event. They’ve got live music, an art gallery, nail bar, wellness lounge, gift wrapping and more, if you can even believe that. Pre-register to get in for $5 or donate clothes at the door for $5 entry.
Thread in SF

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: L'acajou Bakery & Café

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

CARY LANE’S IN-STORE BIRTHDAY PARTY
Friday, November 18, 8 p.m to 11 p.m.
The birthday celebration continues at clothier Cary Lane, who celebrates three years in business with food from La Victoria Bakery and Patxi’s Pizza and sips from Magners Cider, Svedka Vodka, Red Bull and Fuze. And, everything in the store will be an additional 30% off.
Cary Lane

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: The Sage Café

A WAKE FOR 1978 AT DOUBLE PLAY BAR
Friday, November 18, 7 p.m.
1978 in San Francisco was one tough year. Jim Jones and the Peoples Temple (which started in SF) wiped out 918 people and Harvey Milk and George Moscone were assassinated. Tonight, Mike Weiss shares his new film, Double Play: The Hidden Passions Behind the Double Assassination of George Moscone and Harvey Milk , Jack Hirschman will read his poem The Jonestown Arcane along with a few other sharings of accounts of the zeitgeist at the time. It’s being held at Double Play bar, because you’re going to need a drink or ten during the course of this history lesson.
City Lights Books

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Free chicken burrito at El Metate

item.title: The Potrero Hill Kid: Troublemaking in the 1950s
item.description:
Growing up here in the city these days, you can get in to a lot of trouble. But for Mike Bradbury and his “hooligan friends,” trouble in the 1950s meant rolling tires down hills straight in to traffic, turning straws in to spitball guns and stealing candy bars and hubcaps.



Mike says if your family didn’t make that much money, you could live on a street like Rhode Island. His family lived in the "slum section" of Pennsylvania Avenue, but his dad always paid the extra five bucks to get a space in the garage (that’ll get you, what, about 45 minutes at a meter these days?).



He used to go “shopping” (candy bar stealing) at the Hilltop Grocery, which still stands in some form today.



Check out his full blog post for more old-timey photos and to find out where his bad kid ways eventually lead him.

item.title: 50% off The Chameleon Café
item.description:
Scout Notes: His name was Buster, and more times than not, he was hard to find. But that trait wasn’t why owner Melody named her Nob Hill café after her beloved pet. She simply set out to establish an ever-changing space that could adapt to the community it catered to. And at this sunny, spacious spot you’ll find what feels like an extension of a cozy living room: durable naval chairs surrounding substantial tables, a bookshelf of “borrowable” books, a stack of board games and plenty of neighborhood chatter. Over the past seven years, staff and regular patrons have gotten to know each other, so when one guy comes in for his morning coffee, Melody welcomes him back from a long trip to Israel while she pours his drink. Alongside caffeine rich options, you’ll find café fixtures like the popular breakfast bagel stuffed with ham, egg and cheese, a variety of salads and six sandwich choices, including a sunflower chicken salad sandwich. On the whiteboard, you’ll find organic specials like turkey cranberry and Italian combo paninis and empanadas stuffed with grilled chicken and jack cheese or spinach, artichoke and chard, with a side of chimichurri sauce – garlic, olive oil, parsley and spices. On Thursdays, the Mexican menu is extended further when street food favorite El Tonayense rolls up. Enjoy an al pastor taco alongside one of Chameleon’s craft beers or local wines.

Buster may be hiding for good, but we guarantee you’ll find yourself at The Chameleon.

Menu Highlights:
Almond Joy – chocolate, espresso, almond, steamed milk, whipped cream, $3.50
Fresh Baked Pastries from Batter Bakery, $2.50
Fruit Parfait, $5.95
Ham & Brie Sandwich, $6.50
Smoked Salmon Salad, $7.95

Hours:
Monday – Wednesday, 7 a.m. to 3 p.m.
Thursday & Friday, 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.
Saturday & Sunday, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.

item.title: Let Someone Else Do The Cooking
item.description:
Your new favorite brunch, breakfast, lunch, dinner, meals-on-the-go, warm-from-the-oven-treats, evening hang out spot is set to open on December 4th. Alison Clement of Square Meals and Jen Musty of Batter Bakery are taking over 2127 Polk Street with their new joint concept. Alison whips up healthy meals that can be enjoyed in the restaurant as easily as they can be taken home, and Jen provides sweet and savory goodies to complement, like Sweet Potato Goat Cheese Rosemary Scones and Pumpkin Cinnamon Cream Cheese Cupcakes.

SCOUT: So Jen, where did you learn to make all your delicious goodies?
JEN: I am a mom-taught and self-taught baker. I grew up baking, my mom says, from the point that I could stand on a chair next to her. Throughout high school and college, I would always bake if I was bored or stressed out. After college is when I really started tinkering with recipes. I went to school for business and got an accounting degree and started a job in public accounting, but I would sit there at my desk every day thinking What am I going to make when I get home tonight? I started out doing some catering for small business, and it just kind of snowballed from there.

SCOUT: You make so many different yummy treats, is there one thing you especially look forward to making?
JEN: The Fall treats are some that are very memorable for me. The pumpkin bread recipe is something I grew up with. Every October 1st, my mom would make the first batch of pumpkin bread. Gingerbread and applesauce spice muffins, I was eating from the time I was two years old. I’ll open the oven and smell them baking and get transported back to the time I was little.

SCOUT: Yum! Ok, Alison, what was your inspiration for taking healthy food and sticking it in the on-the-go world?
ALISON: When I started cooking, I was a personal chef, so I was already a part of solving the problem of how busy people with young kids can eat a well-rounded diet and fresh foods. It was frustrating to me, though, because it was a high price point, and people had to commit ahead of time to many meals per week. So I kind of backed in to the prepared meals on the go, and for the past three years since I've been working out of a commercial kitchen, you can order meals online and have them delivered. With that, you still need to order 24 hours in advance, though. The new store is the solution to that. It’s not a competition to restaurants, it’s another avenue for eating. I’m also kind of old fashioned, and I think it’s really important to sit down and eat dinner as a family.

SCOUT: Tell us more about the new space:
ALISON: We’re taking the burden off customers, so when you come in, you’ll be able to buy a roasted chicken and a side dish and cupcakes to take home, but only have one credit card to swipe.

SCOUT: How often will the menu change?
ALISON: It will change all the time; we’re not having anything printed that says what we cook. We have two options: you can get the prepared meals that come as a package, or you can mix and match. As a blog post, we’ll announce the main entrées we’ll be cooking for that month, and then the side dishes will always change.

SCOUT: With your beer and wine license, you’re creating a night time hangout, too...
JEN: We want to offer the space as an alternative to a bar. People are out and about non-stop on Polk Street, but we want to create a spot where you can come in and grab a dessert and a wine pairing or a tapas snack and a beer without getting elbowed and jostled in a crowded bar.

SCOUT: What did we miss?
JEN AND ALISON: Drop in during our opening on December 4th. We're going to have lots of fun stuff going on. It'll probably be more like a party all week, actually.

Leave the Thanksgiving cooking to Chefs Alison and Jen. Check their scrumptious, festive offerings below. Email Email Chef Alison or give her a call at 415-552-3501. Email Jen or call 415-994-4944. Orders can be placed and delivered together.

item.title: A Hidden Bomb Shelter Trapped In Time
item.description:
Our beautiful little bay has been the site of many military defenses and fortifications since the Civil War, but it was during the Cold War that we began burrowing deep inside the earth in the event of a nuclear attack. Photographer Mike Hows, of the site TakenPictures, delved deep in to one of the U.S. Navy’s San Francisco nuclear fallout shelters to get a look at what subterranean life was like back in 50s and 60s. It’s a glimpse in to a space where time seems to stand still.

Among dusty desks in the command center, canned emergency drinking water and an instant toilet for 50 people, he also captured disaster control plans and ghostly hospital beds. Click over to his site to check out the full set.

item.title: 100% off El Metate
item.description:
Scout Notes: El metate, besides being really fun to say, is an Aztec word for the stone tools used to ground corn in to tortilla appropriate powder. Here at 22nd and Bryant, El Metate means delicious Mexican food brought all the way from the heart of Mexico by owner Francisco. As a child, he spend countless hours with his grandmother in her kitchen in Guanajuato, learning how to marinate chicken, fry pinto beans in whole black pepper and corn oil for an amazing flavor profile, and come up with a sauce he uses on his fish tacos that’s so secret, the only ingredient information he’s willing to give up is “spices.” The secret sauce is only part of what makes the fish tacos so memorable, though. Each piece of fish comes covered in a crispy batter that’s strictly breadcrumbs, no egg or flour. It’s an original recipe Francisco introduced about seven years ago, and continues to be on the top of everyone’s favorite list.

Also on that list is El Metate’s chicken burrito. There are many ways to make a chicken burrito, but the El Metate way involves juicy thigh meat, fried pinto beans and jasmine rice, which Francisco says is more flavorful than other rices. The heat level is left up to you, with a few sections of the walls devoted to a spicy rack, not a spice rack, filled with every taste bud riling hot sauce you can imagine.

Menu Highlights:
Chicken Burrito, $5.50 (free with deal!)
Fish Taco, $2.75
Quesadilla, $6
Torta, $6.25
Chicken Tortilla Soup (large), $5
Pork Tamale w/ chile verde sauce platter, $7.75

Hours:
Daily, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.

item.title: The Craftiest of Locally Crafted Brews
item.description:
Mmmm. Beer. It does a body good. Ok, maybe not so much, but it’s delicious and makes us feel happy, so that’s good enough. Why go for some generic can of Brand X Light when you sip on brews made here in our own backyard? Last week we asked you:

WHO MAKES THE CRAFTIEST OF LOCALLY CRAFTED BREWS?

OUR SCOUT SAYS:

There are a lot of talented brewers in the city, but the fact that Patrick and Bryan consistently brewed up tasty unique beers in a garage in SoMa puts Pac Brew Lab at the top of my locally crafted beer list. And when I got to sit down with them over one of their delicious Imperial Stouts, well, let’s just say it sent my heart and taste buds aflutter. They recently held their last free brew night in order to move the operation to Devil’s Canyon Brewery in Belmont, but every sip of a Pac Brew Labs creation will always bring me back to the good old garage days.

YOU SAYS:

"I really like 21st Amendment, but only for their seasonal brews. I'm gonna have to go old school on this one and say Anchor Steam still takes the cake. I also like Triple Voodoo."
- Jessica Copi

"In San Francisco? I'll say Almanac. In the greater Bay Area? Drake's in San Leandro."
- George Georgerson

"Thirsty Bear and Magnolia quench a thirst pretty nicely."
- Lance Walker

"Social Kitchen & Brewery!"
- Megan Allison Wade

NEXT WEEK’S WHAT SAY YOU: WHERE DO YOU GO FOR LIP-SMACKING CLAM CHOWDER?

Oh clam chowder, you warm us heart and soul. Where do you go to load up on one of the heartiest soups on the (fish) market? Hit us up on Twitter or Facebook.

item.title: Matt Fleming Cranks Out Some Art
item.description:
When we attended Artcrank at 111 Minna awhile back, there were lots of cool, bike themed posters to check out, but there was one burst of hot pink awesomeness that really caught our eye.

The artist is Matt Fleming, who says he got in to biking when he moved to the Bay Area and realized he could survive without the stress of owning a car. When his dad gave him a Specialized Roubaix, riding became an even bigger part of his life. Here, he tells us about is unusual source of design inspiration and sketches out his own version of “Scoutmob:”

SCOUT: What did your earliest art look like?
MATT: It was some strange stuff. The earliest recollection I have is something that looks like an old jukebox with zigzag borders radiating around it. When I started to draw heavily in third grade, it was a lot of "tough guys" like super heroes or ninjas.

SCOUT: You have a ton of tees in your store. How often do you add new designs?
MATT: The storefront is a nice outlet for me to crank out random design ideas, but that only happens when I have a little breathing room between client work. It's an ongoing side project I’d like to eventually update quarterly to keep interest, and there's quite a long list of ideas waiting for my attention.

SCOUT: Your poster really caught our eye at Artcrank. What was going through your head when you put this bad boy together?
MATT: Thank you! Artcrank has become one of the few projects each year that is dictated 100% by me, and there are no compromises made due to input from other parties. When that's the case, I actually have a difficult time deciding what it is I want to focus on, so I resolved to mix together nearly all the ideas I had. Initially, each one of the little vignettes was a skeleton of a poster idea that I couldn't let go. The overall theme is my progression from using a bike for transportation to riding out of pure joy.

SCOUT: Please doodle us your idea of what a “Scoutmob” is:


SCOUT: Oooooh we like! Ok, you design a lot of band merch (not to mention your artist in residency with The Bay Bridged awhile back). What local bands are playing through your speakers currently?
MATT: Bhi Bhiman, Lia Rose, Matt Nathanson, all in the singer/songwriter genre, and my friends Ghost & The City who are a mix of jazz and indie.

SCOUT: What inspires you?
MATT: Lately I've been artistically inspired by the huge wave of creativity being displayed through the Instagram app. This isn't a plug for a client, it truly is a way to see how people all over the world are expressing themselves. The perspectives, color schemes, juxtapositions, and emotions seem to find their way into my thoughts when sketching out ideas for illustrations.

At lease once a week I make a trip to the local book stores to hunt for sweet covers. That form of art when done well is smart, simple, and one step closer to pulling you into the story. It reminds me to not over-design projects.

Outside the art world, I'm inspired by the support I have from my family and witnessing the hard work and talents of my friends. 

You can check out Matt's poster, and the other Artcrank posters, at Chrome through the end of the week. Take a look at Matt's other work on his site.

item.title: 50% off The Bubble Lounge
item.description:
Scout Notes: We know you work hard, so you deserve to lounge hard. Perhaps you’re familiar with the cozy, romantic interior of The Bubble Lounge, but what you may not have heard about are the amazing food offerings. This tapas menu ensures you won’t have to lift a fork, spoon or knife to get this sustenance into your mouth. I’m talking buttery, flaky filo crusted hearts of palm, finger friendly sandwiches layered with Manchego cheese, prosciutto and green apple, cheese selections, and fresh strawberries with a pot of warm chocolate for dipping. And of course, the proper way to lounge is with drink in hand, which isn’t hard with a full bar, over 25 sparking wines and champagnes by the glass, over 250 by the bottle and tasting palettes featuring some of The Bubble Lounge’s most popular and unique champagnes.

The atmosphere at The Bubble Lounge is as versatile as their champagne menu. Reserve a corner couch in the back to celebrate your next birthday with 30 of your closest friends while staff keeps you supplied with the party juice, or tuck in to a table near the glass patio doors for an intimate date. Friday nights bring The Bubble Lounge’s Tiny Bubbles Party featuring alternative entertainment like burlesque shows, performance artists and DJs that know how to take your hand and lead you straight in to the weekend.

Cheers to that!

Menu Highlights:
Filo Crusted Hearts of Palm w/ Prosciutto & Parmesan, $12
Manchego with Prosciutto and Green Apple Sandwich, $13
Chicken Curry with Green Apple and Toasted Walnuts Salad, $11
Fresh Strawberries with Warm Chocolate Fondue, $12
Perrier Jouet Grand Brut Champagne/Glass, $16
The Bubble Bellini – Prosecco and Peach Nectar, $14
Cashmere & Silk Cocktail – Grey Goose La Poir, St. Germaine, Piper Heidsieck Champagne, $13
Reserve a comfy couch space by calling 415-434-4204

Hours:
Tuesday – Thursday, 5:30 p.m. to midnight
Friday, 5 p.m. to 2 a.m.
Saturday, 6:30 p.m. to 2 a.m.

item.title: 50% off Nico's Tacos
item.description:
Scout Notes: Nico’s Tacos isn’t your typical taqueria, and because of that, we’d like to take you through a little vocab lesson of some of the phrases you’ll see on the menu here. Lesson #1: California Crakslaw – crisp cabbage, carrots and cilantro with a zesty garlic-lime vinaigrette. Lesson #2: Guerilla Sauce – creamy chipotle aioli spiked with achiote (a spice) and Sriracha. Lesson #3: Green Sauce – a creamy blend of avocado, sour cream, cilantro and a hint of lime. The theme here is a California twist on taqueria classics and a So Cal vibe throughout the restaurant.

Mainstays like tacos, quesadillas, burritos, nachos and platters make up most of the menu, but new additions like carne asada fries made with garlic curly fries and green sauce, teriyacos (teriyaki tacos) and weekend brunch chilaquiles (think breakfast nachos) spice up the menu as much as Nico’s homemade orange hot sauce – it’s a high level burst of temperature made with carrots and habanero peppers. Calm the fire with an adult beverage from an array of Mexican imports, or a more local beer like 21st Amendment’s canned IPA. And if you’re feeling really brave, test out the death oil hot sauce, it’s a concentrated concoction of oil from cooked habanero peppers. And if you make it through without steam coming out of your ears, you can rightfully tell people you cheated death.

Menu Highlights:
Baja or Grilled Shrimp Quesadilla, $9
Veggie Soyrizo Brown Rice Bowl, $7.50
Nachos, $7.75
Chicken Tacos, $3.50
Giant Pork Burrito, $8.50

Hours:
Monday – Thursday, 11:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Friday – Saturday, 11:30 a.m. to midnight
Sunday, 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m.

item.title: What to Do on the Weeknights, November 14-17
item.description:
Wouldn’t it be nice if humans were the type of animal that went in to hibernation to survive the winter? We could just feast our little brains out and then curl up under a mound of blankets only to emerge once the elements are a little less harsh. But, as much fun as that sounds, we don't want to miss out on this:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

THANKSGIVING DINNER PARTY AT THE HUB
Tuesday, November 15, 6:30 to 8 p.m.
Here’s a good way to avoid the “I’m so full, I’m scared I’m going to pop” feeling you always get at the Thanksgiving dinner table: start training now. The Hub workspace is hosting a Thanksgiving Dinner at their SF office (Organic Roasted California Turkey, Heirloom Mashed Potatoes with Garlic Gravy, Sweet Potato Pie with Marshmallows, nom nom nom), and you're invited. Be sure to wear a long shirt in case you need to loosen your belt halfway through.
Tickets are $35

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Cumaica Coffee

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

DIY HOLIDAYS AT 18 REASONS: PERSIMMONS
Tuesday, November 15, 7p.m. to 9 p.m.
If you’re thinking What the heck is a persimmon? right now, check out this little photo reference for clarification. During this class, you’re going to learn more about the persimmon than you thought existed, including folklore and history, drying them, making candy from them and how to create charming gift baskets to share your new favorite fruit with your friends and family.

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Luna Park

ICE RINK IN UNION SQUARE
Through January 16, Times and Tickets Here

Union Square Ice Rink

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: SB40

item.title: (Bacon) Crack Comes To Fatted Calf
item.description:
Yep, that’s right, we’re encouraging you to indulge in a little crack. Bacon crack, that is, from the Willy Wonka mind of Kai Kronfield, the man behind popular dessert pop-up, Nosh This. So what’s in bacon crack? You better locate a tissue, because what you’re about to read is going to make you drool. Start with fried-to-a-crisp bacon mixed with butter-toffee, almonds and salt dipped in 72% chocolate. Hey, we warned you.

Kai’s treats are available in 10 stores around the Bay, including seven in San Francisco, and now he’s teaming up with Hayes Valley’s beloved charcuterie provider, Fatted Calf, to add their bacon-y deliciousness to his already mouthwatering treats. We’re talking bacon dry-rubbed with brown sugar, sea salt and spices and smoked over applewood. Kai says when he met a Fatted Calf staff member at one of his events, he told him he needed to be in the store, and from there, the fit was just natural.

Nosh This debuted the Fatted Calf Bacon Crack last Wednesday during Fatted Calf’s pork happy hour with samples of the famous goodies. They’re now available for sale at the Hayes Valley and Napa locations.

Follow @NoshThis and @fattedcalf to make sure you don’t miss a bite of what these innovative foodies are up to.

item.title: 50% off Coffee Adventures
item.description:
Scout Notes: Usually, anything even close to the vicinity of Fisherman’s Wharf is a no go zone for locals due to the heavy tourist population running rampant through the area. That’s understandable, but we shouldn’t deprive ourselves of one of the most beautiful parts of SF, and we really, really shouldn’t keep ourselves away from what is, in my travels and extensive taste tests, the best chai latte I’ve ever had. Owners Bob and Nicole know a lot about coffee (they say their coffee snobbery keeps them on top of the best ways to get the most out of a bean, like using cold pressed espresso for iced drinks, not watered down coffee), but you’d swear they invented the chai latte after you taste this thing. Using loose leaf tea, cinnamon, cardamom, cloves and Coffee Adventures’ own sweetening base (which I swear is made with magic and rainbows) they whip up a chai that’s creamy, silky and wholly addicting.

The food menu boasts fresh pastries, paninis and salads, but it’s the daily specials that are the real sellouts, in the good way of selling out, I mean. Monday brings a spicy-ish jambalaya with sausage, rice and vegetables, Thursday is vegan chili and on Fridays you can dip in to Kickin’ Crab Sweet Corn Chowder. Which should all, of course, be accompanied by a side of chai latte.

Menu Highlights:
Chai Latte (small), $2.70
Avalanche Smoothie – ice cream or yogurt w/ espresso, white chocolate syrup, caramel syrup, $3.75
Bistro Bagel Scram – bagel w/ egg, artichoke hearts, tomato, spinach, $4.50
Chicken Panini w/ southwest chipotle pesto, provolone cheese, $6.50
Portabella Mushroom Panini wi/ basil pesto, fire roasted red pepper, spinach, provolone cheese, $6.50
Monday Special: Jambalaya – sausage, rice, vegetables, mildly spicy, $5.50

Hours:
Monday – Friday, 7 a.m. to 6 p.m.
Saturday – Sunday, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.

item.title: What to Do This Weekend, November 11-13
item.description:
Eleven, eleven, eleven! Or, 11-11-11. Looks a little more like binary code than a date. Oh nerd jokes! Regardless, we still won’t be able to remember what day it is, but we would never, ever forget to mark our calendars for this:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

DOUBLE FEATURE AT CASTRO THEATRE + SCOUTMOB TREAT
Sunday, November 13, Shows start at 2 p.m. & 7 p.m.
This Sunday will feature more Queen than the Castro Theatre’s ever seen. At least thanks to Queen's rock score, heard throughout Flash Gordon. Stay for Dune and you’ll be rewarded with four foot tall shots of Sting’s abs. Bring your not-yet-converted-to-Scoutmob-friends to the 4:10 or 7 p.m. shows for a buttery, salty treat.
Castro Theatre

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Ike’s Place

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

FALL LUXURY CHOCOLATE SALON AT FORT MASON
Sunday, November 13, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
The holiday season is synonymous with chocolate. Or maybe it’s just our lives that are synonymous with chocolate... either way, the Fall Luxury Chocolate Salon is the time to indulge with over 30 chocolatiers, confectioners and wineries. Get all your holiday gifting done here while fueling yourself through the shopping frenzy with bursts of chocolate.
Advance tickets are $20

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: La Canasta

MOVIES ON THE BUS WITH CHICKEN JOHN
Friday November 11, 8 p.m.
Bet you never thought you’d be voluntarily boarding a bus with SF local Chicken John, but he’s inviting everyone aboard for a night of the movie Network with intermission at a secret tea garden in Oakland then over to Grizzly Peak during the last half of the movie. The bus takes off from Ritual Roasters at 8 p.m. sharp!
Admission is $20

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: South End Grill ‘n’ Bar

item.title: 50% off Marmalade Boutique
item.description:
Scout Notes: When’s the last time you went shopping with $100 and actually came home with change? And I’m not talking about a trip to the dollar store. Here at Marmalade, that’s exactly what you’re going to get: an exciting change in your wardrobe, along with some change in your pocket, because nearly everything in the store is priced well under $100. And out here on Union Street, that’s basically unheard of. With brands like Michael Stars, Collective Concepts, Kersh, Sanctuary, Ella Moss, Splendid and Veronica M offering up pieces that can go from desk to dinner, work to weekend, so you’re getting even more bang for your buck. Lucky Magazine even described Marmalade as “Anthropologie style with an H&M pricetag."

But you won’t have to hunt through racks and racks to find your new favorite dress; Marmalade is a cozy (say hi to Clementine the goldfish in between trying on your new finds) store with carefully selected pieces that staff (all are trained stylists) can help you piece together in to an outfit to match your personal style. And, everything is ordered in small shipments with new merchandise hitting the shelves up to three times per week. That’s insurance you won’t run in to a million other girls wearing the same top. But as long as it’s from Marmalade, is that really such a bad thing?

Boutique Highlights:
Splendid Tops, $52
Collective Concept Dresses, $68
Volcano candles, $28
Peppermint Tea Scarves, $24
Marleybone & High Street UK Cardigans, $58
Sanctuary Denim, $68

Hours:
Monday – Saturday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.
Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.

item.title: Not Your Grandmother’s Scavenger Hunt
item.description:
When a scavenger hunt starts with slurping down beers from something called “Bongzilla” and dodging water balloons being thrown at you from rooftops, you know it takes a certain breed to emerge victorious. Such is the case at the California League of Adult Scavenger Hunters events. Their next venture will take participants through the wild streets of the Castro in Tight & Bright, neon spandex required:

SCOUT: How did this whole thing come about?
CLASH: How did it blossom?

SCOUT: Yessssss, how did it “blossom?”
CLASH: We started by trying to make a league out of scavenger hunts, much like soccer or some other sport, and it didn’t really work that well, but the result is what we have now, which is CLASH in it's current for, with hunts every Saturday night, sometimes Fridays. But, we’re going to take another shot at the league early next year.

SCOUT: So how does a typical hunt begin?
CLASH: Way back when, we started them off in parks, but one time we brought out a bottle of Jameson and gave people shots before the teams took off, and since then, we’ve moved the start to bars.

SCOUT: Social lubrication. Brilliant. So then what?
CLASH: About half of the people shows up with their team of 5-6 players and the other half shows up as individuals or pairs, and we put them in to teams. Once everyone's arrived, we do some ice breakers. Sometimes we do an alley obstacle course involving beer, although the cops have been called a few times, and then we launch the teams off.



SCOUT: And then during the hunt?
CLASH: The hunts usually last one and a half to two hours, and we have people dressed up as characters along the way, so there’s people to find, planted objects, strangers they have to interact with, even bonus points for spraying another team with silly string. The teams are taking photos the whole time, and a bit of drinking along the way, and when they get back to the bar, we download their photos and tally up their scores. Sometimes we have a bonus round, like a dance off, and we project the best photos from the night inside the bar and then declare the winners.



SCOUT: So basically, your job is to make up games. That’s like the coolest thing ever.
CLASH: Yes, it is.

SCOUT: What would your ultimate, dream scavenger hunt look like?
CLASH: With CLASH, we usually stick to one neighborhood, so it would involve a few different neighborhoods and a few different modes of transportation. Like those little yellow cars that you see all around the city, we’ve talked about getting a limo involved, so that would be part of it, public transportation... a lot of characters... and a lot of people on rooftops throwing water balloons at all the players.

SCOUT: Wow. Like a real life video game!
CLASH: Exactly! And also, there would be live animals. Tigers and zonkeys, maybe. Just something really extreme.

SCOUT: Like hard hats required?
CLASH: Hard hats, climbing up buildings, just pushing the limits.



SCOUT: So tell us more about CLASH moving in to the league scene here in a few months.
CLASH: We’re going to have a Tuesday night league that goes for four weeks, it’s called the CLASH Cup. And then our big hunts will just be one Saturday every month.



Sign up for CLASH’s next hunt here, and like ‘em on Facebook and follow them on Twitter @clashsf for more league news.

item.title: How To Overcome Name Attention Deficiency Disorder
item.description:
There once was a man from Nantucket, whose name we can never remember and end up having to awkwardly introduce him to friends hoping he’ll take the initiative and say his own name first. Thankfully, for those of us who are faint of mind when it comes to remembering names, there’s a new app about to hit the block called Namerick, which promises, through science, to help you out with your Name Attention Deficiency Disorder.

Ok, so what’s a namerick? According to the creators, it’s “a mnemonic device that utilizes imagery and alliteration to make a name more memorable.” Basically, once you meet someone, you wait for the chance to input their name in to Namerick (it auto-fills using US Census data for faster input), make notes on the person’s profession/relationship to you, then press the Generate Namerick button which generates a memorable imagery and alliteration based off the person’s name. The app will also send you follow up texts reminding you of the person’s name so you can really get it ingrained into those little brain synapses.

Check out the video for a tutorial and inside look at what else the app can do.



Namerick just launched, so download the app for free now. We wouldn't want you to forget later.

We’re digging you, Namerick, now what can you do about helping us remember where we put our sunglasses?

item.title: 50% off Indie Industries (North Beach)
item.description:
Scout Notes: At Indie Industries, you don’t have to look for local tags to make sure you’re supporting your fellow city dwellers, all you have to do is look for an Indie Industries label on the garment or accessory you’ve got your eye on. The brand was founded in NYC by fashion design grads who brought their work together to form one strong company. Word quickly spread, and after getting picked up by over 50 retail shops, the design studio made its way west, eventually landing in San Francisco. You’ll find simple, solid color t-shirts, rainy weather scarves, neon limited edition jelly belts, and more, all stamped with the Indie Industries name. All good designers have a mass of inspirations, which is what the rest of the store is packed with. You’ll find top selling dresses from made-in-California companies like Do & Be and MBD, and skirts that can keep up with the San Francisco weather by looking great paired with bare legs or tights. And for the gents, vegan hooded jackets that make you look as badass as Lorenzo Lamas in Renegade.

But the art isn’t only wearable here at Indie Industries. There are shelves of items for a little fun in the kitchen as well. Cutting a cake is fine, but with a plastic kitchen Table Saw by Fred, you can carve that bad boy. Even the salt shakers look a little more museum-worthy than kitchen cabinet find. And of course, anything emblazoned with a mustache is sure to catch our eye, which in this case comes in the form of a wine opener. Yep, we’re pretty sure we can’t live without it.

Menu Highlights:
Do & Be Geometric Dress, $42
Eklah Metallic Tribe Top, $32
Qupid Black Heel Boots, $42
Nuco Men’s Plaid Shirt, $39
Custom Rags Vegan Hooded Leather Jacket, $89
Sunglasses, $16
Plastic Kitchen Table Saw, $8

Hours:
Monday – Saturday, noon to 10 p.m.
Sunday, noon to 8 p.m.

item.title: Dog Tricks for City Humans
item.description:
San Francisco is a city of dogs. But dating complaints aside, this place is teeming with canines wagging for a walk. Everyone’s got special spots and secret tricks to owning a dog in the city, so here’s a quick insider’s guide to where to go, how to get there, and what to do if you’re craving a pup of your own.

Story and Illustrations By Rose Garrett

Transportation

Good old-fashioned walking your dog is the best way to get to where you’re going with some exercise thrown in. But if you’ve got miles to go, SF public transpo might consider throwing you a bone

MUNI: If you don’t have a service dog, prepare to muzzle and leash your hound and travel only outside of the peak commuter hours of 5-9am and 3-7pm, which is kind of a bummer. And according to official MUNI rules, a fare equal to the owner’s must be paid for each non-service animal.



BART: Allows pets to be brought aboard at no additional charge, but stipulates that your animal “must be secured in a container that is specifically manufactured for transport of a pet,” which may work for your Chihuahua, but not so much for your Great Dane. Pets at-large or on a leash or harness (other than service dogs) are not permitted.

Caltrain: Has the stingiest policy of them all, allowing only service dogs onto their trains, with no exceptions. The workaround? Get your dog certified as an Emotional Support Animal (hey, we’ve all got issues), and you can take him on board with you every day. One Caltrain perk? Puppies in training for Guide Dogs for the Blind may board Caltrain at any time, so keep your eyes open for potential cute overload.

Dog-Friendly Spaces

Dogs need room to roam, and SF has a bunch of options of choose from, whether you’re going for city parks or more rugged terrain.

Parks: Duboce Park is a classic, but such out-of-the-way spots as Bernal Park and Glen Canyon make for more secluded dog-walking. Visit the almost-secret Corona Heights Park for a dog run with a breathtaking view of the city (multitask by bringing a date on your evening walk and a visit to smooch castle is almost guaranteed).



Beaches & Fields: Look to Fort Funston for a vigorous off-leash outing. Other options for letting your dog wild and free are Baker Beach (north of Lobos Creek), Land’s End, Crissy Field and Ocean Beach. Dogs should always be under “voice control,” so if your dog has discipline issues, consider taking him to training before letting him off the leash.

(Doggie) Style

Folks in SF probably pay more attention to their dog’s duds than their own (and it shows. Zing!). These SF purveyors provide local products for poochie:

Timbuk2: The messenger bag maker’s Muttmover pack is perfect for biking with your smallish dog.

GwenGear: Choose from SF-made collars, harnesses and leashes in a myriad of colors and patterns.



George: Another SF company that covers the gamut from doggie tags to beds and sweaters—since 1991!

Get Your Own

Do you frequent dog parks to stare creepily at other people’s pets? Maybe it’s time to get a pup of your own. These spots are the first places to look for canine companions:

Rocket Dog Rescue: This volunteer-run rescue organization saves dogs from being put down at over-crowded shelters and finds them loving, happy homes.

Wonder Dog Rescue: Wonder Dog rescues neglected puppies, elderly dogs, and everything in between, providing foster-care, medical care and adoption services.

SF SPCA: This go-to for all your adoption needs has the system down pat. Visit the SPCA to adopt a pet, or just to “look” at the impossibly cute kitties and pups (and then accidentally on purpose adopt one anyway).

Rose is pretty awesome, isn’t she? How to live in the city with a dog is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to all the cool stuff she knows about in SF. Check her out on Twitter @rose_garrett.

item.title: Mark Your Territory: Checking In The Old School Way
item.description:
Well before there was Foursquare to let people know the mayor was in the house, all we had to rely on were animalistic basics like marking areas with our ahem biological matter (read: pee). Welp, one guy has engineered a check in system that helps you Mark Your Territory using an inherent behavior and new technology (read: “check-in to foursquare by physically urinating at the actual location”).

The "meditation" hopes to maintain the technology of Foursquare while drawing humans back in to the physical world and providing additional information to others such as:

+Check-In Gradient – How "there" were you?
+Unbiased Profiles – A description of yourself that you cannot cheat
+Cross-Species Communication – Squirrels knows nothing of your Foursquare status but can tell where you peed
+True Ephemera – Maintenance of a physical reputation is demanding (and rewarding)
+Indirect Environmental Restructuring – Explicit marks fade, but one's impact on a physical environment is permanent.

This video should explain the many unanswered questions you probably have right now:



And for how easy it seems to be to to relieve oneself on the sidewalk in SF, you should have no problem adopting this new way of checking in.

item.title: 50% off SB40
item.description:
Scout Notes: If you don’t know where SB40 is, it’s all in the name. It stands for South Beach Pier 40, which is exactly where you’ll find this seafood-focused neighborhood sports bar. From this spot, you can take in a Cal game on one of the flat screen TVs while enjoying picturesque views of the U.S. Coast Guard vessels bobbing just outside the window. The glass top tables are covered in old timey San Francisco maps, perhaps a nod to the location’s original business, Carmen’s, which fed longshoremen in the area from 1957 to 2010. The ocean theme continues into the menu with starters like fresh oysters and lobster focaccia and entrées like the signature Boston-style lobster roll. But if you’d rather just look at the ocean than eat from it, the SB40 burger is a top seller. It comes piled with arugula, caramelized onions, house pickles and piri piri pepper with ocean views at no additional cost.

The beer list is still growing, but already boasts staples like the dark and smoky Full Boar Scotch Ale and SB40’s house ale, which is similar to Sierra Nevada with a little less hop. And on our coveted sunny SF days, post up at one of the outdoor tables and watch the traffic along the Embarcadero. If it gets too overwhelming, shift slightly in your seat to bask in the serenity of the ocean and the deliciousness of your fresh catch.

Menu Highlights:
Fresh Oysters, $2.50
Lobster Foccacia, $9
Boston-style Lobster Roll, $22
SB40 Burger, $11
Full Boar Scotch Ale, $5
SB40 House Ale, $5

Hours:
Monday, 5 p.m. to 9 p.m.
Tuesday – Thursday, 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m.
Friday – Saturday, 11:30 a.m. to 11 p.m.
Sunday, 11:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.

item.title: Milkshake It All Around
item.description:
Why isn't it called a milkblend, or a milkmix instead of a milkshake? We've only made a few of those bad boys in our day, but we don't remember much shaking going in to it. Perhaps it's because we start shaking with excitement whenever we get to slurp one of 'em down. Last week we asked you:

WHOSE MILKSHAKE BRINGS YOU TO THE YARD?

OUR SCOUT SAYS:

Go big or go home, right? When I let myself indulge in the creamy goodness of a milkshake, I like to go huge. For me, that means heading to Pearl's Deluxe Burgers for a craving killing Nutella shake. Add banana, and you could almost consider it a part of a well-balanced breakfast.

I also have to throw a shout out for the spiked milkshake at Super Duper, because even the most professionally made White Russian can't compare.

YOU SAYS:

"Super Duper."
- Sophia Chung

"Mel's"
- Helena Celdran Green

"Chile Pies & Ice Cream."
- Aylwin Po Villanueva

"The pecan pie shake at Goin' Coastal is tasty!"
- @Tyrusasaurus

NEXT WEEK’S WHAT SAY YOU: WHO BREWS UP THE TASTIEST LOCALLY CRAFTED BEER?

Anchor Steam may have been around since before The Big One hit, but they're not the only brewers in the game. Hit us up on Twitter or Facebook and let us know whose beer has you saying Once it hits your lips, it's so good!

item.title: Food For Thought
item.description:
We all know you should start your morning with a big healthy breakfast in order to have a good day, and Mission Graduates, a non-profit organization, helps K-12 students in the Mission start their lives off right by arming them with the support they need to get in to college.

Next Wednesday, with the help of Mission businesses, they’ll hold one of their biggest fundraisers, Food For Thought, when restaurants will donate up to 50% of profits for that day to Mission Graduates. Nearly 30 restaurants are participating this year, and seats are filling up fast! Choose a restaurant from the list and make a reservation now.

That’s some of the most delicious food for thought we’ve ever come across.

item.title: What to Do on the Weekdays, November 7-10
item.description:
We hope you took advantage of that extra hour of sleep you got this weekend. Whether that means you were up extra late Facebooking stalking, er, "researching" that blind date you have this week, or actually sleeping is totally up to you. And if you forgot to adjust your clock and showed up at work at an awkward time, make sure it’s all sorted out by the time these events roll around:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

FARMERS MARKET HAPPY HOUR
Wednesday, November 9, 2011 from 5:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.
We’ve been eating our way through the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market for years, and now we’re learning we can drink our way through, too. CUESA and the Northern California Chapter of the United States Bartenders Guild are picking the best fall produce straight from the farmers’ stalls and mixing up some chilly weather cocktails to warm your heart, soul and body. Bites will also be appropriately paired. It’s the last happy hour of the season, so grab your ticket now.
Tickets are $35

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Fuzio Universal Bistro

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

FREE CONCERT WITH YEAH YEAH YEAHS DRUMMER
Tuesday, November 8, 8 p.m.
Ok, so you might not think of the cello as an instrument that would have a place in modern music, but Brian Chase, drummer for the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, says it isn’t so, and he’s teaming up with the four talented musicians from North Sky Cello Ensemble for a free show at Brick & Mortar. Show up early if you have any hopes of getting in.
Brick & Mortar Music Hall

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: We Be Sushi

BLEK LE RAT: 30TH ANNIVERSARY RETROSPECTIVE
Thursday, November 10, 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m.
If you like Banksy, you’re gonna love Blek Le Rat. He’s one of the original modern street stencil graffiti artists, and a new book showcasing his art is available in the Museum Store and on display at the MOMA for a public viewing. The event is free, but we can’t promise you won’t be able to resist picking up a copy of the book.
SFMOMA

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Bar Basic

item.title: 100% off Ike's Place (16th St)
item.description:
Scout Notes: It’s somebody's birthday today. But it’s ok if you forgot a card, because you’re the one who’s going to be opening a birthday gift. Consider it a thank you for all you’ve done over the past four years. In 2007 (on today’s exact date), Ike Shehadeh, Ike’s Place’s owner, opened a regular ole sandwich shop and didn’t sell a thing (hard to believe, right?). He re-opened in November and was lucky to sell nine sandwiches. He decided to get a little creative, and voilá – the Elvis Kieth was born. As the menu continued to grow, so did the business, until the original location had to close and Ike was forced to look for a larger space. After a short stay at temporary location that greatly tested the business, he’s finally settled in to his new spot on 16th near Sanchez, and thanks to your insatiable appetite for his sandwiches, things couldn't be going better. Even after three closures and two moves, Ike’s fans have been loyal and 2011 will bring record sales. As if Ike hasn’t thanked you enough by supplying you with consistently delicious sandwiches, he’s now giving away the creation that sparked a sandwich revolution.

Besides a list of sandwiches that could supply you with a new choice every day of the week for months, Ike’s followers know it’s all about the famous dirty sauce. It’s a garlic aioli that’s not only brushed in to the fresh bread baked here (gluten free also available!), but generously drizzled over all the ingredients before the sandwich is topped off with another piece of bread and wrapped tightly in brown paper for your to-go convenience.

We’ve been to a few birthdays in our time, but the goody bags we got on the way out the door don’t even come close to what you’ll find in your Ike’s brown bag. Happy birthday, Ike’s Place, and you are so welcome.

Menu Highlights:
Dirty Chips, $1.50
Bottle Drinks, $2.49
Can Drinks, $1
Menage A Trois – halal chicken, real honey, honey mustard, bbq, pepper jack, swiss, cheddar, $11.11
Matt Cain – roast beef, turkey, salami, godfather sauce, provolone, $9.99
Paul Reubens – pastrami, homemade poppy seed coleslaw, french dressing, swiss, $9.99

Hours:

Friday – Saturday, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.

item.title: What to Do This Weekend, November 4–6
item.description:

item.title: 50% off Bella Ceramica
item.description:
Scout Notes: It’s now November, people. Aside from prepping yourself for a ton of turkey and mountains of mashed potatoes you also have to start thinking about holiday shopping. It’s once again that most wonderful time of the year–unless you decide to wait until Black Friday to get your loved ones something special, then it’s just miserable. Or even worse, what if you don’t know what to get them? Allow Scoutmob to make a suggestion: Bella Ceramica, offering the largest collection of fine Italian ceramics in Northern California.

Because the store is owned by Italian immigrant Claudio Luporini and his family, the extensive collection of ceramic goods that you see on display here are imported from the Italian region of Umbria–where Claudio knows many of the artists personally. Walking into their downtown location is very much like making your way into a gallery: artful pieces delicately line the walls, many of them of 4th generation craftsmanship; unique hand-painted patterns that have been handed down through hundreds of years.

Although the San Francisco store is just celebrating its one year anniversary, the Luporini family has been beautifying the homes of Bay Area-ites for over a decade from their original location in Oakland. Claudio brings style into your life with elegant dishware and dining sets, evoking pastoral scenes of the old-world countryside. It’s a lot more affordable than buying round-trip tickets to Italy. And, if you come in on Saturday, they’ll even validate your parking. Mamma mia!

Store Highlights:
Italian Proverb trays from Deruta, $18.95
Simonetti hand-painted eggs from Castelli, starting at $40
Simonetti hand-painted ornaments, $50-$125
Niccacci Della Robbia pieces from Deruta, $50-$150
Ceramic mugs from Deruta, Gubbio, Palermo and Siena, $40-$60

Hours:
Monday – Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.
Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Closed Sundays

item.title: With Rice Paper Scissors, Everyone Wins
item.description:
They’ve been featured in the New York Times and even got a visit from Anthony Bourdain, but Katie Kwan and Valerie Luu say they started their popular Vietnamese food pop-up, Rice Paper Scissors, simply because they “wanted to cook and serve people food on the street because that’s the way we enjoy eating.” If you’re ever walking down the street and see a cluster of little red stools, take our word for it, you HAVE to stop:

SCOUT: How did you two meet?
VALERIE: We meet when we were both hustlin’ Vietnamese street food at the Underground Market -- I was the Vietnamese crepe peddler, Katie was roasting whole pigs for her famous Banh Mi Burgers.
KATIE: Quite the love story.

SCOUT: When/how did the idea for Rice Paper Scissors form?
KATIE: Five days before Tet, the Vietnamese New Year, when Valerie had the idea to get together and sell Vietnamese food in celebration of the coming new year.  What better way to do so than to line the street with little red stools and sell the Vietnamese food we have eaten through our travels and past experiences? Five days later, we found the perfect cherry blossom filled terrace, bought stacks of little red stools and cooked up crab glass noodles, stuffed fried chicken wings, and sea snail pho for 100 hungry eaters.

SCOUT: Take us back to your first big, official pop up. How did you feel going in to it?
VALERIE: We felt an incredible high trying to put together a concept, menu, gig poster and find a space in just a few days. Everything had to come together so fast, we had no time to second-guess ourselves. We’re also lucky to have talented friends who are down to help with our crazy stunts: our friend Jessica Taich whipped up our first gig poster in an hour, my boyfriend Iso was there taking orders while Katie’s BF Andrew was helping her cook, and the original PizzaHacker (aka Jeff Krupman) was there to untangle our Christmas lights -- super crucial.

SCOUT: You guys cook every Thursday at Mojo Café. Does it make it any easier to work in a kitchen you’re familiar with?
KATIE: We really enjoy cooking at Mojo and making it our Cheers spot. Every Banh Mi Thursday, we get to spend time with our friends and customers in a cozy cafe. Plus, we can work on perfecting our dishes without the added need to set up and break down a kitchen.
VALERIE: Yeah, the less schlepping, the better.

SCOUT: What are some of the challenges of having your kitchen on the street?
KATIE: Setting up and breaking down, working with the San Francisco micro climates, and packing coolers with dry ice, are some of the less glamorous parts of the job. However, hitchhiking (as a last ditch effort) to our gig, working with different space allotments, and approaching small businesses to see if they are interested in hosting an RPS are some of the happy challenges that keep us on our toes. Valerie and I learned about cooking by selling street food so I would say the sidewalk is as familiar a kitchen as any.

SCOUT: Think you’ll ever have a brick & mortar?
VALERIE: Hopefully!  We’re more likely to open a brick and mortar than a food truck.  The thought of parallel parking a beast of a truck makes me anxious. For now, we’re happy to call Mojo Cafe our home.

SCOUT: What did we miss?
RPS: We are thankful to all of the people who have lent their time, skills, and spaces to Rice Paper Scissors. Without them, this wouldn’t be quite the endeavor that it is.

Follow @ricepaperscissors and sign up for their Tipsheet to find out where they're popping up next.

Illustration by Tom Smith

item.title: You Are Listening To...
item.description:
Ambient music. You hear it in elevators, artsy car commercials, and maybe even in your head before you nod off to sleep. It’s sleepy time music designed to stabilize your heart rate and make you feel like you're being swaddled in a big, fluffy cloud. Throw in a live feed from a police scanner, though, and the mood changes a bit.

Eric Eberhardt, video game product manager and website producer (and sometimes artist, apparently), has mashed the two together to create something that honestly sounds a little otherworldly. Suddenly, reports of road rage and the possible sighting of a handgun don’t sound so scary set to the sounds of swirly acoustics.

Right now it’s only the CHP feed, but after listening to Eric’s creation for awhile, there’s a whole heck of a lot more that goes down on the streets beside flat tires and speeding. We’re digging you, ambient music/police scanner mashup, because we never thought experiencing someone getting pulled over could be so relaxing.

Thanks to Uptown Almanac for alerting us to this coolness.

item.title: 50% off Indie Industries (Castro)
item.description:
Scout Notes: Feeling Fashionable? Indie Industries covers your back--and most other parts of your body as well, offering men's and women's clothing, accessories and designer jewelry all designed locally here in the Bay. In fact, much of what you see in their new Market & Castro location was created right in the store itself. With its own live design studio, customers can watch a crew of talented local artists as they fabricate the jewelry and assorted artful apparel that gives this shop its prolific personality. We’re talking a happy hodge-podge of fabrics, foot-ware, fixtures and furnishings. Denim, graphic Ts and re-purposed necklaces are just some of the alluring items that highlight this eclectic ensemble. You’ll also find a bevy of small treasures that await your discovery. Don’t be surprised if you leave the store with a new set of light bulbs. Or if it’s too bright you can get yourself some cheap sunglasses, for under $20.

And the artists aren’t just employees, they’re also the bosses here at one of the city’s only designer-owned collectives. Sure, you could go to a traditional department store and separate yourself from all this pesky creativity, but...you live in San Francisco, for cripes sake! Winter is on the way. Stave off the cold with that warm and fuzzy feeling that comes from supporting your friendly neighborhood design collective.

Indie industries is at the threshold of art and style, somewhere between fashion boutique and showroom. So step inside and wrap yourself in inspiration--although one of their reasonably-priced scarves would also do the trick.


Store Highlights:
Leather wallets made in SF by FullyCo, $24
Handmade earrings and necklaces by Jenn Kubat, starting at $16
Belts made to order by Jawn McQuade, starting at $14
Graphics Tees made in-house, starting at $18
Hand blown glass terrariums by Mike Stone, from $16-$85

Hours:
Monday – Sunday, 12p.m. to 9p.m.

item.title: San Francisco’s Forrest Gump
item.description:
The movie Forrest Gump, was just that, a movie. While it would be fun to imagine one person could possibly have been involved in just about every poignant moment in history from the 50’s to the 80’s, it just seems a little... unbelievable. Lawrence Ferlinghetti’s life seems a bit similar to Forrest’s, only there’s no script or well rehearsed acting here. He founded City Lights Books (where he sold Allen Ginsberg’s Howl and was arrested on obscenity charges for it) in 1953, studied at Columbia, the Sorbonne and the Academie Julien in Paris, and has shared his poems and paintings all over the world.

This Friday, at the majestic Meridian Gallery, Lawrence will read his newest poem At Sea. His friend and fellow poet, Jack Hirschman, will join, reading from his new Arcana before the two settle in to talk about the amazing lives they’ve lead while we all listen, wide-eyed.

Tickets are $10-$20 and available at the door or through Brown Paper Tickets.

item.title: Win A Prize If You Recognize
item.description:
How well do you know your city? Give us your best guess on this mystery location and we'll send a sweet, sweet prize to one lucky winner.

Reply to the Scoutmob daily email with your answer, or hit us up through Twitter or Facebook.




Last week’s answer: The Fry-fecta at Roam Artisan Burgers
Last week's winner: Yvette Cuca

item.title: 50% off Mark's Bar
item.description:
Scout Notes: Polk Gulch has such a sweet ring to it. It hearkens back to a golden age, when Polk’s long commercial strip between Market and Geary was a high-end glamour destination for glitterati all over the city. Owner Mark Aloiau remembers that era well, and is ready to help usher Polk Street into its renaissance period. With his brand-new venture, Mark’s Bar, he colonized the old Lush Lounge space at Polk and Post, re-purposing it with a bright, Asian flair (think fresh, tropical flowers, intricate wood carvings, and parasols). Aloiau has been getting to know his neighbors, shopping nearby for everything from fresh fruit to the gorgeous salvaged wood bar. The space is classy, but the drinks are affordable. Happy hour prices are $3 for domestic beers and $4 for well drinks, with all-day specials like $7 for a Tecate and a shot of 1800 Silver tequila. And for the fancy crowd, Mark has hand-crafted a portfolio of artisan cocktails, including the Ginger Manhattan, with light rye whiskey, Cointreau, ginger syrup, and muddled cucumber; the Wasabi Martini (exactly what it sounds like); and the Island Style, with Cîroc coconut vodka, guava, orange, and lime juice, and grenadine. Mark’s Bar also serves a Tahitian beer called Hinano that’s remarkably addictive, not to mention hard-to-find.

Which is all to say that this right now is your chance to get in on the goodness while this bar is still in its infancy. Before its old school charm is discovered... and you end up having to jockey for position at the bar. Trust us: it’s a treat.


Menu Highlights:
Ginger Manhattan, $10
Wasabi Martini, $10
Island Style Cocktail, $10
Tecate and a shot of 1800 Silver Tequila, $7
Hamms and a shot of George Dickel whiskey, $7

Hours:
Monday - Friday, 3 p.m. to 2 a.m.
Saturday - Sunday, 1 p.m. to 2 a.m.

item.title: 50% off South End Grill 'n' Bar
item.description:
Scout Notes: Mac ‘n’ Cheese?  Yes, please!  It’s always a smart move venturing into the warm confines of a friendly neighborhood eatery, but you need not be a genius to step up to this Mac bar. Boasting 10 varieties of the comfort food classic, South End Grill ‘n’ Bar satisfies the senses with an assortment of dazzling dishes that fill your belly with deliciousness and your mind with the memories of meals that mom used to make–if she happened to be an incredibly talented cook.

Owner Steve Silver is half Jewish, half Asian and wholly charismatic. His menu is equally as eclectic, offering Italian specialties, like irresistible Chicken Milanese, alongside chic Chinese fare, like seared Hangar Steak on a billowing bed of bok choy. The food is sensational across the board, but the prices are downright unbelievable: enjoy a hearty entrée along with a pint of one of their six rotating Northern California micro-brews for around $15 (or half that, if you’re dining with the ‘Mob)!

In addition to fan favorites like the Carbonara Mac–infused with green peas, crispy bacon and zesty Parmesan cheese–South End also dishes out finger friendly bar bites like pulled pork sliders and spiced rubbed wings, but don’t be surprised if you find yourself coming back to the mac ‘n’ cheese bar. Be forewarned: the crackly crunch of fried breadcrumbs atop a smattering of tasty cheeses is highly habit-forming. Casual and considerately quaint, South End Grill ‘n’ Bar fits perfectly into our cozy City By the Bay. Simply good food by a lifelong neighborhood native: a recipe for many happy returns.

Menu Highlights:
Mac ‘n’ Cheese w/ cheddar, jack, Parmesan, and breadcrumbs, $7.50
Carbonara Mac, $10
Chicken Milanese served w/ arugula, mozzarella, and tomato, $12.50
Asian Hangar Steak served w/ bok choy, $12.50
Angus Beef Burger served w/ fries, $8

Hours:
Monday – Thursday, 5 p.m. to 10:30 p.m.
Friday & Saturday, 5 p.m. to 11:30 p.m.
Closed Sundays

item.title: Getting Dressy For The Holidays
item.description:
November 1st. There may not be a Hallmark card for it, but it is the official beginning of the holiday season. For the next two months, you’ll be gift shopping, whipping up potluck dishes, and party hopping. And you’ve gotta look good throughout the whole storm. Last week we asked you:

WHERE DO YOU GET OUTFITTED FOR THE HOLIDAYS?

OUR SCOUT SAYS:

I get overwhelmed by ginormous department stores that seem to have racks and racks of choices, so much so, that I end up leaving with nothing. So the first time I popped in to Revolver and realized I would love to wear anything from their carefully selected wardrobe, it shot to number one on the list of stores I hit on shopping adventures. Be sure to check out the backroom, which is half art gallery, half super awesome sales rack. Hm, maybe I can get an advance on my Christmas money.

YOU SAYS:

"Ambiance on Haight!!"
- Nikki Marucut

"Nothing says holidays and shopping more than a spin through Macy's."
- Adam Arlington

"The boys at The Common make me look like I actually know something about fashion."

- Will Boston

"I feel ready to take on the chaos of the holidays in anything from Acrimont."
- Angela Mason

"Mingle on Union is my favorite spot no matter what time of year."
- Vanessa Spano

"I can always find something elegant but original at Painted Bird."
- Armisen Matthews

"I never leave Welcome Stranger empty-handed."

- Jack Richardson

NEXT WEEK’S WHAT SAY YOU: WHOSE MILKSHAKE BRINGS YOU TO THE YARD?

When you were little your mom always encouraged you to drink your milk. Welp, she’s not around, so we’re encouraging you to drink your milkshake. Who mixes up this most delicious indulgence? Hit us up on Twitter or Facebook.

item.title: Arianna Orland Makes Posters That Rock
item.description:
It started with the need to get her hands dirty, and a little inspiration from a phrase she saw stenciled in the Mission. Arianna Orland makes “words to live by” on “posters that rock.” So what does that look like? Just like this:

She’s constantly scribbling down notes with new phrases, but only a few make the cut:

SCOUT: You gotta tell us, where did the inspiration for your posters come from?
ARIANNA: As a designer who spends most of her time on the computer, I was looking for a way to get back to the roots of my craft and my profession so I decided to take a letterpress class. The first class project is to print any phrase you'd like. I have to say it was kind of a daunting moment. It felt a bit like I'd been mute my whole life and could suddenly speak a complete thought for the first time. Many years ago in the Mission District of San Francisco an artist had gone around stenciling phrases on the sidewalk to a lover. One of the phrases was "Love Me Till My Heart Stops". I took a photo of that and had it on my desk for  years. When it was my turn to choose a phrase to print, those are the letters I pulled from the drawer. After I saw them on the page I realized how powerful a few well chosen words could be.

SCOUT: They’re so simple, but catchy. How do you decide on what’s poster-worthy?
ARIANNA: I keep a running list that I add to whenever a phrase comes to mind. You never know when you'll get a good idea; they end up on paper, notes in my iPhone, on the back of my hand. Before printing a new edition, I go through the list with Steve (partner at Activate Design Studio) to make the final edit. We usually end up with several from the running list and one or two that sneak up at the end in one of those "awww yeah...that's the move right there...we have to do that one" kind of moments.

SCOUT: Are there any phrases you try to live your life by/find especially meaningful?
ARIANNA: Depends on the day. I spent this weekend in Los Angeles with my family. Right about now I'm feeling Today Was a Good Day 

SCOUT: You say that your posters are “hand pulled.” What does that mean exactly?
ARIANNA: All posters are printed by me, by hand, on a Vandercook letterpress using 10 line gothic wood type. I cut the paper, I set the type, I ink the press, I feed the sheets, and walk them down the press one at a time.

SCOUT: Where do you do your printing?
ARIANNA: I printed the first edition at Studio on the Square in New York City. The second edition was printed at the San Francisco Center for the Book.

SCOUT: You currently have 12 posters in the “San Francisco collection.” Any plans to add more?
ARIANNA: Yes, look out for the next collection on the new year. 

SCOUT: You started the posters as a way to get out from behind the computer and dirty your hands up a little bit. Any other crafty projects in the works?
ARIANNA: I have a tatt.ly, design temporary tattoo, coming out soon. And I will be at the Renegade Holiday Craft Fair. 

Get your hands on Arianna’s posters at Paper Jam Press.

item.title: Dip In To These Fantastic Fry Spots
item.description:
Drinking (which we don't doubt you'll be doing a little of tonight) and fries go together like vodka and soda. Some people might say fries are the perfect side dish, but put a plate of these crispy, fried deliciousnesses in front of our face, and we can make a meal out of it. It all starts with the fry, but can reach other worlds paired with the right dips. We rounded up just a few of our favorite fry dishes, from the French version to the Peruvian and a few more in between.

All images via Foodspotting



NOPA’s LINK Kennebec French Fries and Red Pepper Feta Dip ($6)
Spotted by Pei Ketron



Absinthe’s LINK French Fries with smoky tomato ketchup and sweet-onion aïoli ($6)
Spotted by Sylphi

Spotted by Fox W



Jake’s Steaks LINK Waffle Fries ($4.29)
Spotted by Pixelboy



Limon Rotisserie’s LINK Yucca Fries ($3), Aji Sauces: Rocoto, Aji Amarillo, Chimichurri (.75 ea) Spotted by James Guigayoma

item.title: What to Do on the Weeknights, October 31 – November 3
item.description:
We’re partied out, and technically Halloween just started. Darn you holidays that fall on weekdays, you always throw us off. At least if we stay in tonight, we can get up early to wait for the stores to open so we can buy up all the discount Halloween candy. And we’re not holding back, because our planned events this week are all completely free:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

GHOST WALK AT CITY HALL
Monday, October 31, 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m.
Politics can be scary. SF City Guides says Civic Center used to be the site of a cemetery, and that’s just one of the spooky tidbits you’ll learn about during this free tour. It only happens once a year on All Hallow’s Eve, and even though you might be scared out of your wits, leave your mace at home, you will be subject to a security search.
SF City Guides

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Barrel Room Wine Bar

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

ONE CITY ONE BOOK: MARY ROACH IN CONVO WITH ADAM SAVAGE
Wednesday, November 2, 6 p.m.
Even if you haven’t read Roach’s Packing for Mars, you’ll still enjoy her talk with MythBuster’s Adam Savage. This is the best-selling, Oakland author’s 4th book, and the talk will start with a premiere of Rockets of Yesterday, a video tour of 50s and 60s rockets. Seating is limited, so we recommend getting there as early as possible.
One City One Book

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Cumaica Coffee

ALTERED BARBIES AT SHOTWELL 50
Through November 20, Mon–Sat: 1 p.m. to 8 p.m., Sun: 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.
A little hair of the dog for you when it comes to spooky, ghoulish, gruesomeness. Barbie may be one of America’s most recognizable icons, but not after these artists get to her with some scissors, glue and other craft materials. It's the artistic form of plastic surgery.
Shotwell 50

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: HANGR 16 Boutique

item.title: 50% off Pizzeria Avellino
item.description:
Scout Notes: Pizzeria Avellino is old school. So old school, they not only have the staple red and white checkered tablecloths on all the tables, but the Giants memorabilia on the walls is from back in the day when the team called New York their home. But, that all makes sense since this pizza joint specializes in thin crust, New York style pizza. With whole milk mozzarella cheese from the happiest cows in Wisconsin and your choice of 15 toppings, including meatballs (duh, it’s an Italian restaurant), atop daily made dough (a family recipe from the owner’s grandparents), you’re gonna be asking who this Avellino is and how he gets his pizza to taste this darn delicious. Avellino is actually a city just outside Naples, Italy, the birthplace of all things pizza-licious. Personalize an individual slice, or go for the whole shebang, like the regular’s favorite Lombard Combo, a heavy sprinkling of pepperoni, sausage, mushrooms and black olives. And for dessert, another pizza, the Nutty Pizzetta, topped with hazelnut, chocolate cream and chocolate chips.

In the mornings, the smells of mozzarella and fresh dough give way to coffee beans when Pizzeria Avellino transforms in to Café Avellino and serves up fresh brewed caffeine to Cow Hollow residents and everyone headed into the Presidio for work. Grab a bagel (pizza’s more portable cousin) stuffed with bacon and cheese to hold you over until the Pizzeria opens at 11. Look for a full brunch to make its way on to weekend menu soon, because we all know there’s nothing wrong with pizza for breakfast.

Menu Highlights:
Lombard Combo – pepperoni, sausage, mushrooms, and black olives, Large $24.50
Meat Lovers – pepperoni, meatball, bacon, Large $23.50
Cheese Slice, $3 (add .50 per topping)
Caesar Salad, $6.75
Nutty Pizzetta, Small $6.75, Large $9.50

Hours:
Cafe:
Monday - Friday, 7 a.m. to 11 a.m.
Saturday & Sunday 7:30 a.m. to 11 a.m.
Pizzeria:
Saturday & Sunday, 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Monday & Tuesday, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.
Wednesday & Thursday, 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Friday, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.
