item.title: 50% off Pacific Catch (Chestnut Street)
item.description:
Scout Notes: I really dislike standing around waiting for things, especially when my stomach is rumbling. Thanks to the power of the internet and a little pre-planning, you can have your Pacific Catch order in your hands as soon as you step off Chestnut and through the door. Place your order online as soon as you feel the first bit of hunger, and by the time you swing in to grab your food, your stomach will be doing happy cartwheels. How fast you can rip open the package and get it in your mouth is up to you.

Pacific Catch is well known for its seafood offerings, but if you’re in the mood for something a little more “landfaring,” the Marina location now serves juicy, marinated grilled steak that can be added to any dish. Tucked inside an island taco and topped with crispy sweet onions, cabbage and Sriracha aioli, you’re gonna wonder where this dish has been all your life. And for the seafood lover, you’ve come to the right place. Hawaiian poke, salmon, mahi mahi, shrimp, ahi... I don’t think I need to keep tantalizing your taste buds. Add it to a salad, a sandwich, a taco or a rice bowl and you might be pushing your chopsticks aside for the biggest spoon you can find.

If ordering online, show your Scoutmob deal at pickup and your credit card will be refunded the proper discount amount.

Menu Highlights:
Sweet Potato Fries w/ ginger wasabi aioli & sweet thai chili sauces, $5
Pacific Steak Taco Platter w/ fries or salad, $11
Japanese Wasabi Bowl w/ Grilled Salmon, $13.50
Chipotle Mahi Mahi Salad, $12
Spicy Ahi Sandwich w/ fries or salad, $11
Agave Sparkling Lemonade, $3.50

Hours:
Daily, 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.

item.title: What to Do This Weekend, October 28-30
item.description:
Hopefully you’ve already locked down your Halloween plans and have five transportation backups planned for how you’re going to get around town all weekend. Lord knows you’re not getting a cab, and probably not a bus either. We got so desperate one year, we flagged down a delivery truck who ever so graciously delivered us to our house party destination (and we weren’t even wearing a sexy costume!). You’ll be partying the night away, but we’ve got you covered for that time of day when the zombies and vampires are safely tucked away:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

MUSTACHE RIDE OVER GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE
Saturday, October 29, 1 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.
Who wants a mustache ride?! You provide the bike and mustache, and The Mustache Riders will make it happen. This is a pre-‘Movember event, and since you’re going to need strength and stamina to give it all you’ve got next month, it’s a good thing you’re training now. Don’t forget to bring some cashola for the ferry back.
More details

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: La Canasta

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

LEARN HEROIC TAROT READING
Sunday, October 30th, 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.
What better way to scare the bajesus out of your friends than predicting their futures using tarot cards? This Sunday, at the city’s House of DIY, workshop, learn “Major and Minor Arcana, the Court cards, and the the elemental suits.” Then go home and practice your serious face for when the Death card gets flipped over.
Details

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Fillmore Street Café

COME OUT AND PLAY
Saturday, October 29, 7 p.m. – Sunday, November 6, 6 p.m.
“Can Timmy come out and play?” This version of Come Out and Play is only for the big leaguers. With the entire city as your game board, you’ll participate in over 15 free, real-life games that make regular old Capture the Flag look like the easiest thing in the world.
Full game schedule & details

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: La Victoria Mexican Bakery & Café

item.title: 50% off Tony's Cable Car Restaurant
item.description:
Scout Notes: Sock hops, drive-ins, soda jerks and going steady; to some of us, these are things we’ve only ever seen in Grease, to others, it’s the good old days. Tony’s Cable Car Restaurant, operating from the same location (with virtually the same menu) since 1972, is a step back to a time before Shape-Ups, street food carts and phone accessories that clip on your ear, if you can even imagine. Here, you can still get a quarter pound hamburger for under $5 and a shake so thick, you might want to start working your mouth out now to ensure you can conquer it.

It’s well after lunch hour by the time I jump off the 38 and scoot up and down the hill to Tony’s Cable Car Restaurant, but this place is hopping like the clock just struck noon. Just like in the good old days, it’s cash only here, which you hand through the order window before picking up your meal at the other window. The choices are simple and don’t go far outside the hamburger, chicken, hot dog range. Tony’s most popular item has always been the deluxe beef burger with a hunk of cheese melted on top, and really the meal isn’t complete without a side of crinkle cut fries and a milkshake. Milkshakes come in chocolate, vanilla, strawberry, banana, pineapple and coffee, which can be mixed together to create whatever your little heart desires. Nostalgia never tasted so good.

Menu Highlights:
Cash Only
1/4 lb Cheeseburger, $5.48
Vegetarian Burger, $5.39
Grilled Chicken Breast Sandwich, $5.39
All Beef Jumbo Chili Dog, $4.11
Idaho Crinkle Cut French Fries, $2.42
Thick Old Fashioned Milk Shake or Malt, $3.32

Hours:
Monday – Friday, 9 a.m. to 9:45 p.m.
Saturday, 9:30 a.m. to 9:45 p.m.
Sunday, 9:30 a.m. to 8:45 p.m.

item.title: This Isn’t Your Regular Ole Farmers Market, Folks
item.description:
Things you’re used to seeing at farmers markets: apples, lemons, flowers, maybe even some organic honey. Things you’re not used to seeing at farmers markets:


Video by Warholian

And that’s because this isn’t just a farmers market, it’s The Farmers Block, an “ecological pairing between art, music, and food, mostly local organic farms, and vegan/raw chefs, sometimes food trucks/carts” all wrapped up for your pleasure in one live event. This growing crew lives by “zenliness,” which is their term for when art, music, and food are paired properly in a sustainable, ecofriendly manner, and they want you to be a part of their collective:

SCOUT: You sort of took the farmers market idea and injected some fun in to it. What was the inspiration?
FARMERS BLOCK: My life and being in general. I've always cared about health and had a growing interest in holistics and dietary alternatives. Coming from that past, I think that's how I was subconsciously inspired. Consciously, I was inspired in many ways from thinking deeply about sustainability, networking, collaborating, trading and overall community. The places I shopped for produce and food, be it farmers markets, or major super markets, were not as uplifting as I thought they could be. I felt that a high level of passion was absent from the equation, although the exception is the Ferry Building and Alemany Farmers Market, both of those being quite the distance for getting to and from. This all lead me to launching The Farmers Block. What was missing from the overall picture, to us, was a place to gather goods, sell, barter, or exchange the crafts, art, products of eco-friendly design, and healthier foods by way of connecting the friends that were within our existing circle.

SCOUT: There are many different people involved in The Farmers Block (diggers, chefs, farmers, artists, musicians, filmmakers, & entrepreneurs, probably just to name a few). What does a typical event look like?
FARMERS BLOCK: We ideally bring out 20 artists, 20 fashion designers, 10/20 farms and chefs, also sustainable organizations and other grassroots collectives, pack the stages with beat producers/turntablists/emcees/musicians and top it off with visual art, like projections, and vj's. Everyone being local, and within the same community.

SCOUT: You work at Treasure Island Job Corps and Mission Kitchen, to name a couple. What is it like to work in an environment with other people you’re not necessarily collaborating with?
FARMERS BLOCK: It's great! If we’re cooking around others that aren't collaborating with us, we let them in on what TFB is doing and what foods/recipes we’re coming up with. Usually they are interested in helping or getting involved somehow after that. Food really brings people together no matter what.

SCOUT: What’s the most important thing our Scouts should know about The Farmers Block?
FARMERS BLOCK: We want you be proactive and get involved with us! We’re completely grassroots, and not going to go the corporate route, we stay underground and for the people. Our collective is a brand, and coalition not just an event. If you’re an artist, musician, chef, farm, designer, activist, naturist, blogger, or creative in general, feel free to reach out to us!

And here’s where you can do that, and follow The Farmers Block to make sure you make it to their next event: Tumblr, Facebook, @thefarmersblock.

item.title: Re-discovering Kaleidoscopic Fun
item.description:
The resident turnover in San Francisco seems to be just as consistent as the images in a kaleidoscope. That’s why we want to introduce you to (and remind some of you about) a public art installation on Octavia that’s been adding whimsy and mystery to the area since 2005. Wang Po Shu, through the San Francisco Arts Commission, installed 12 kaleidoscopes as part of his “Ghinlon/Transcope” piece. Their placement stretches from Octavia Boulevard and Market all the way to the Hayes Green.

If you’ve never found yourself traipsing around this area, you probably had no idea they exist, but we can tell you these public kaleidoscopes are well worth the stop (just remember to always look both ways before crossing the street). Wang Po Shu used a unique mirror lens to allow viewers to take in the surrounding scene and put a new spin on it. The sculptures can swing 60 degrees up and down and 180 degrees from left to right, so if you get bored of an area, one little pivot provides a whole new world.



Photo by Todd Lappin of Telstar Logistics

We’re digging you kaleidoscopes, because sometimes, re-discovering is just as special as the initial discovery.

item.title: 50% off The Blue Muse
item.description:
Scout Notes: If you know anything about your Greek mythology, you know that the word muse comes from the names for any of Zeus and Mnemosyne’s (ya, don’t even try) nine daughters who represented an art or science. The Blue Muse restaurant is in the middle of one of the city’s most artistic areas – it calls the Davies Symphony Hall, the War Memorial and Performing Arts Center, Bill Graham Auditorium and the San Francisco Ballet, neighbors. And the other part of the name? It just came to the restaurant’s owner “out of the blue.”

Most French restaurants come with white linen table cloths, duck entrées and a good wine selection, all things you’ll find at The Blue Muse, but this restaurant has something you won’t find at most other French restaurants: super friendly staff. None of that snooty, nose up in the air, if you don’t pronounce that impossible French word correctly I’m going to openly roll my eyes attitude. But even though the service is more casual, the food is still upscale and high quality. The mozzarella sticks aren’t something you’d ever find in a sports bar, these are mozzarella cheese stuffed with prosciutto and served with a side of tomato relish. Mains range from pastas to fish to chicken to duck (of course), all of which can be enjoyed alongside a specialty cocktail from the full bar.

Also, keep your eye on The Blue Muse’s Facebook page for upcoming events. The big concert venues aren’t the only ones putting a show on around here.

Menu Highlights:
Golden Fried Brie Cheese, $8.95
Cold Cucumber Soup, $6.95
Shrimp Fussili, $16.95
Breast of Chicken Provencale, $18.95
Veal Sweetbread, $18.95

Hours:
Monday – Friday, 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Saturday & Sunday, 9:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.

item.title: Win A Prize If You Recognize
item.description:
How well do you know your city? Give us your best guess on this mystery location and we'll send a sweet, sweet prize to one lucky winner.

Reply to the Scoutmob daily email with your answer, or hit us up through Twitter or Facebook.




Last week’s answer: Cafe Flore
Last week's winner: Eileen @ Ritual

item.title: Giving Twitter The Bird
item.description:
Would a Coca-Cola with any other logo taste as delicious? Would an Apple by any other name spark a worldwide frenzy any time a new product was released (ok, probably)? One of the most recognized logos in modern history (meaning since the beginning of the 2000’s) is Twitter’s blue bird. We like their design so much, when the fail whale pops up, we aren’t even that mad. But, what if Twitter had gone with another type of bird over the cheery little bluejay we’ve come to love? The website designcontest.com re-imagined the logo, and came up with some that were cute and cuddly and others you might expect to pop up in a bad dream:


Aberthol


Alwyn


Amathaon


Angor


Avaon


Barris


Bedwyr

These designs are pretty rad, but don’t mess with what’s not broken, right?

item.title: 100% off Turtle Tower (SoMa)
item.description:
Scout Notes: Every time I hear the name of this restaurant, inevitably, the tune of that popular late 80’s animated series featuring four of the toughest turtles ever goes jangling through my head. The turtles fought evil and the SoMa location of this Vietnamese restaurant is fighting hunger. The name Turtle Tower is synonymous with pho, which is what they’ll be dishing up for you for this deal, but don’t expect all the bean sprouts, basil and other accoutrements you’re used to seeing atop pho. Chef Steven Pham brings the simplicity and freshness of his native northern country recipes to San Francisco with pure broth and wide noodles cooked twice a day and flavorful, free range chicken. It may not be the chicken noodle soup your mom used to make, but the quality is superior and Chef Steven’s expertise is undeniable, and in a shared table setting, the company might be a tad livelier (don't tell your mom we said that).

No traditional Vietnamese meal is complete without some sort of roll as a starter. Choose produce-packed spring rolls stuffed with fresh shrimp and grilled pork, deep fried imperial rolls brimming with crab, shrimp, ground pork, black fungus, silver noodle and more, or the newest addition to the menu, the texture-iffic banh cuon, steamed rice sheets stuffed with ground pork.

Turtle Tower recently added a dinner menu available only at the SoMa location; which is just down the street when you think about the fact you’d have to go all the way to Vietnam to get it otherwise.

Menu Highlights:
Phở Gà (Chicken Noodle Soup, small), $6.20
Gỏi Cuốn (Spring Rolls), $5.15
Nem Cua (Imperial Rolls), 2.15 (each)

From the Dinner Menu:
Vit Ham – pressure cooked duck, $14.95
Mì xào hải sản – egg noodle with assorted seafood, $12.95
Rau Xao/Luoc – mixed vegetables, $12.95

Hours:
Monday – Saturday, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.

item.title: Time Out For Winey Adults
item.description:
We're lucky to live smack dab in the middle of one of our nation's biggest wine supplying areas. That means the good stuff floweth like water around here, albeit at a slightly higher cost. And when the mood strikes you to reach for the red, white or bubbly, you've got plenty of options. Last week we asked you:

WHERE DO YOU GO WHEN YOU'RE FEELING WINEY?

OUR SCOUT SAYS:

Que Syrah is one wine bar I am willing to go out of my way to get to. Not only do I love the witty name (in Spanish, que sera means whatever will be), but the chef also cooks up the most scrumptious dishes for pairings, like the upcoming Pork Rib Paella and Iberian Wine Tasting on November 12th.

YOU SAYS:

"Hotel Biron"
- Jessica Barry

"‎Dell'Uva in North Beach. HUGE selection of wine, super knowledgeable staff, they have amazing food and best of all, it's not snobby. It's the type of wine bar that you go to and watch the game on TV. The music is usually something fun and upbeat. And they have plenty of sidewalk seating, perfect for those amazing nights that we've been having. Whenever I'm feeling the need for some wine and good company, I'll head over to Dell'Uva and without fail, have an awesome experience. Every time. :)"
- Katt Katsumi

"Side Bar by the Good Hotel on 7th is newly remodeled and has very reasonable prices!"
- Joshua Lim

"Press Club - only if you want the best!"
- Jai Singh

"Yield Wine Bar in the Dogpatch hood and Internos Wine Bar near USF."
- Rita Chretien

"Heart"
- Shelley Gladwin Estelle

"TERROIR!"
- Kyra Brown

NEXT WEEK’S WHAT SAY YOU: The holidays are coming. That means lots of parties, and lots of fancy outfits you're going to have to wear to make sure you look your best. Which store do you depend on to hook you up with the coolest duds? Hit us up on Twitter or Facebook.

item.title: D.I. Why Don’t You Do It Yourself?
item.description:
“I wanna do it!” This phrase is usually heard coming from the mouth of a bratty toddler, but thanks to all the DIY spots in the city, you can now utter it and sound confident, not whiny. We put together a list of the best spots to get your hands dirty and make something that’ll have mom bragging to all her friends:

TechShop
“What do you want to make?” With over 90 classes scheduled and open hours from 9 a.m. to midnight, TechShop will teach you everything from making stained glass masterpieces to how to weld steel and aluminum. Even though you can learn how to turn a sweater in to a pencil skirt here, the focus is more hardware than sewing store.


Workshop
If you’ve never been to one of Kelly Malone’s productions, you might not be a local. Whether learning how to make wine from a kit, mastering smokey eyes and nude lips or supporting local artists at Indie Mart, Workshop lets you unleash your creative power all under the careful guidance of a trained professional.





Skillshare
Skillshare encourages you to go both ways. Not like that! At Skillshare, you can “learn anything from anyone,” thanks to a sharing of skills (ah, now it’s all coming together). We Culture Hunted it a few weeks ago and can’t wait to make our very own sock money friend.





The Bike Kitchen
We haven’t seen official numbers on how many cyclists live in SF, but the San Francisco Bike Coalition has 12,000 members and counting, so we’re going to guess a lot. The Bike Kitchen is where bike enthusiasts go to give their wheels a tune-up, or even build the darn thing from scratch.





Any other gems out there we missed? Let us know about your favorite DIY spot on Twitter or Facebook.

item.title: Baller Meatballs
item.description:
Meatballs. Balls of meat. Doesn’t sound super appetizing when you break it down like that, but we all know these Italian goodies come second only to pizza. Mission Fruition’s Carina Ost knows a thing or two about these meat-packed spheres, and says she’s so fond of them, she’d even take a page from The Wedding Singer and let little old ladies pay her in meatballs.

There is an Italian, with East Coast/Jewish influences, gourmet-to-go spot near my house called Pasta Gina, I just call it Dammmmn, Gina that serves up some delicious balls and is my regular go to joint. But when we are talking sit down restaurant and a serious meatball no one makes a bigger, better ball than Tony’s Pizza Napoletana. You must, I repeat, must order a Meatball Gigante with Sea Salted Burrata ($13). The meatball is absolutely enormous with burrata on top. It is such a major meatball that it definitely wouldn’t fall off the table with a sneeze, unless maybe it was done by a giant.

I get a bit baffled about how something so large can be so evenly and perfectly cooked but I don’t worry much as I am too busy sticking my knife and fork into this monstrosity. It is the size of a softball or a grapefruit and each piece of the ball gets re-dunked in the sauce for extra coating and then forked with fresh burrata and ribbons of basil. This dish is truly a victory and is a great starter for those who won’t or can’t be satisfied with just pizza alone. The meatball gigante also comes in more fun options like wild mushroom, pancetta, and robiola or with a farm egg and calabrese but for me I like the cheese, please.

Meatballs aren’t the only thing on Carina’s list when it comes to Tony’s Pizza Napoletana. Find out what other dish she says she will not go without.

item.title: 50% off 31 RAX
item.description:
Scout Notes: Two weeks was all it took for Stephanie Madrinan to get her store, 31 RAX up and running. This airy, vaulted-ceiling space use to house a gym, so when she moved in, Stephanie made use of the metal scraps, lockers and other materials the previous owners left behind to erect dressing rooms and clothing racks. Building her store out of recycled materials just made sense since that’s the basis of what she sells here: vintage-thrift clothing she hand-picks during bi-monthly trips to one of the nation’s biggest fashion capitals: L.A. Even though the clothes are from down south, the styles Stephanie chooses would look good walking down Valencia for a cup of coffee or waiting in a brunch line in Hayes Valley. While the pieces are quintessentially SF-thrift, the store and prices are not. In fact, the organization and cleanliness of the store and clothing has caused some passersby to peer in and comment “Hm, looks expensive.” But with dresses going for $15 and all guy’s t-shirts priced at $9, you could easily pull together a try-on pile without checking one price tag. When’s the last time you did that?

31 RAX just opened its doors last month, but keep an eye on the store’s site for upcoming event announcements. Stephanie’s already hosted speed dating (two attendees are now dating!) and bingo and has a whole list of fun ideas up her her fashionable sleeves.

Boutique Highlights:
Skirts, $12 – $15
Dresses, $15 – $18
Guy’s T-shirts, $9
Flannels, $15
Vests, $10 – $12

Hours:
Monday, 1 p.m. to 8 p.m.
Tuesday – Saturday, noon to 8 p.m.
Sunday, Closed

item.title: What to Do on the Weeknights, October 24-27
item.description:
'Twas the week before Halloween and all through the city, people readied their costumes: Angry Birds, Charlie Sheen and sexy kitty. Ok, actually, we hope you all are planning something a little more original than that. And, since official Halloween falls on a school night, you can wear your costume all weekend, non-stop and no one has the right to give you any guff about it. Don’t worry, even if you're wearing a cape, you'll fit in perfectly here:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

SPOOKY ART OPENING AT PUBLIC WORKS
Thursday, October 27, 6 p.m. to 10 p.m.
“Nights of Darkness” takes over Roll Up Gallery this Thursday, but they’ll leave the lights on so you can see the spooky art that will be bringing a little black to the white walls. Seven artists will be sharing their sinister art at this free event.
More Info

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: HANGR 16 Boutique

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

THE MAKING OF THE BAY LIGHTS
Wednesday, October 26, 5:30 p.m.
The Bay Bridge is going to be just a tad brighter come this time next year when Ben Davis’ ginormous art installation (seven times the scale of the Eiffel Tower) is installed. $20 gets you beer, wine, appetizers and probably a lot of jaw dropping once you hear Ben’s stories.
Tickets are $20

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Bar Basic

RAW: Fashion + Music + Art
Thursday, October 27, 7:30 p.m. to Midnight
Whoever said San Francisco doesn’t know how to dress has obviously never attended a RAW event. It’s a fashion show set to a jivin’ DJ, featuring only the work of local artists. Tickets are $10, and remember to iron your finest duds, this is a cocktail attire event.
More details

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Turtle Tower

item.title: 50% off Hobson's Choice Bar
item.description:
The Scoop: A Hobson’s Choice is thinking you have options, when you really only have one. The term dates way back to an English stable owner who, in order to rotate the use of his horses, would offer riders the horse in the stall near the door, or nothing at all. At Victorian punch house Hobson’s Choice, in the Haight, there a ton of drink options on the menu, including a gargantuan shareable punch bowl that could quench a horse’s thirst (and get him really wasted). But even though it might seem like Hobson’s Choice is offering you a bevy of beverage options, they’ve slyly provided you with one main choice, no matter what you select, and that’s guaranteed lip smacking, rum-based cocktails.

Scout Notes: The sign on the window says “Victorian,” but one foot through the door and you’ll get a sense of the general theme on your own. The red chairs and small, round wooden tables (about the size of a punch bowl, you might say) give Hobson’s Choice an old timey, parlory, saloon feel, almost to the point that you expect to see a boa-wrapped lady of the evening posted up near a piano that’s cranking out some Charlie Chaplin-esque music. The cocktail list here has an undeniable tropical vibe thanks to ingredients like Cruzan coconut and banana rums, pineapple and lime juice and blue Curaçao. Drinks like the Barbados Punch, made with Bacardi spiced rum, Cruzan orange rum, lime and pineapple juice and Cruzan pineapple rum and the June Bug, Midori, Cruzan coconut and banana rums, pineapple juice and sweet and sour are a nice taste of what Hobson’s has to offer, but when else can you get a Prom-worthy punch bowl filled with your choice of three different kinds of punch? Yes, people, the punch bowls are where it’s at. Ladies and gentlemen, your choices are: Victorian Punch – silver, coconut and pineapple rums, cranberry and pineapple juice. GoGo Punch – raspberry, citrus and silver rums, organic lemonade, pineapple juice and a splash of ginger. House Punch – silver rum, mango, orange and pineapple juice. See? Sometimes having one choice is a good thing, especially when it comes to trying to pick between scrumptious bowls of booze.

Menu Highlights:
Drinks:
Pineapple Upside-Down Cake – Cruzan pineapple & vanilla rums, lime & pineapple juice, $7.50
Bahama Mama – Cruzan banana & coconut rums, Kahlua, pineapple juice, sweet & sour, $7.50
Zombie – Cruzan light rum, Brugal gold rum, Whaler’s dark rum, lemon & pineapple juice, $8
Dark & Stormy – Gosling’s black seal rum & ginger beer, $6.50
House Punch Bowl, $30

Hours:
Monday – Friday, 1 p.m. - 2 a.m.
Saturday, noon to 2 a.m.
Sunday, 10 a.m. - 2 a.m.

item.description:

item.title: What to Do This Weekend, October 21-23
item.description:
Historical zombies grape stomping. That’s what you’d get if you combined all of this weekend’s can’t-miss-em events. Sounds a little scary, but we’ve probably seen worse just walking around the city. This weekend, it’s all about getting outside, with the occasional stop off at the bar, of course:

WE DON’T WANT TO MISS:

ZOMBIE PUB CRAWL
Saturday, October 22, 7 p.m.
Sometimes, after a hard night of drinking, we feel like death. Start the night out that way during the Zombie Pub Crawl. Make sure to come dressed in torn, blood spattered clothing, otherwise someone may try to bite you. Three stops are scheduled, but when you’re a zombie, you’ve got all the time in the world, to party hardy for as long as you feel like it.
Zombie Pub Crawl

100% OFF! DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Bob’s Donut and Pastry Shop

ALSO WORTH CHECKING OUT:

BARBARY COAST TRAIL WALK
Sunday, October 23, 9 a.m.
“Your favorite city, right at your feet.” Explore some of San Francisco’s most historical spots on this 3.5 mile walk from the Old Mint to Aquatic Park. Guides in costumes will lead the way, pointing out the areas you should pay special attention to... there may be a pop quiz later. The walk ends at the Maritime National Historical Park with a party that will be one for the history books.
Barbary Coast Trail Walk

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: La Canasta

GRAPE STOMPING BASH AT THE WINERY
Saturday, October 22, noon to 5 p.m.
Come Saturday, you could be squishing through a barrel of grapes if you play your cards right and have $45 to spend. In addition to stomping the crap out of some fruit, you’ll also get to taste new wines from The Winery and get a chance to win wine and barrel sampling for 10 people.
Tickets are $45

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: Fuzio Universal Bistro

BONUS EVENT!
POSTAGRAM + SCOUTMOB: THE 1197 AFTER-PARTY
October 22, 6:30 p.m. to 9 p.m.
1197 is a one day mobile photo conference, but we’re gonna keep this party going allllllll night. Or at least until 9. We’re teaming up with Postagram for an after party at 111 Minna where you will enjoy food from the dynamic duo at Rice Paper Scissors, drinks, dancing and new prints by four very talented Twitterers. Free entry and open to everyone!
More details

DEAL NEARBY ON THE APP: L’acajou Bakery and Café
